hints.content: Recall that if $\theta$ is an angle in standard position, the point, $P$, where the terminal ray of the angle intersects with the unit circle is $P= (\cos{\theta}, \sin{\theta})$.

The angle $\dfrac{\pi}{2}$ is shown in standard position on the grid below.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: The image shows a coordinate plane with the unit circle drawn and an angle in standard position measuring pi over 2 radians. The point where the terminal side of the angle intersects with the unit circle is at x = 0 and y = 1.

hints.content: Note that the point where the terminal side of the angle intersects the circle is $(0,1)$.
Since the $y$-coordinate of that ordered pair corresponds to the sine of that angle, we have that $\sin{\dfrac{\pi}{2}}=1$.
